instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3115: What is 820-3115? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGD? ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present when PP1V8_S3, PP5V_S3, PP1V2_S3, PP1V05_S0, PP5V_S0, PP3V3_S0, & PP1V5_S0 are present and working. If any of these rails is not working, ALL_SYS_PWRGD will be pulled down and the machine will not turn on. .
definitions.R7402: What is R7402? Resistor between PPVIN_S0_CPUIMVP and CPUIMVP_TON. TON stands for TIME ON â€“ CPUIMVP_TON configures the buck converter for the CPU based on its input power supply. If this resistor is blown, the machine will turn on but not have any image, chime, or POST, because CPU vcore will be missing. This resistor is often the first to corrode because it is along a high voltage rail and it is right on the edge of the board, check this on 2011-2012 model Macbook Pros that turn on and do not chime. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no cpu vcore
threads.message:
Hi guys,
having a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> board, powers on, green light and all power rails are there except CPU VCORE.

the board got liquid spilled around the SMC area and <CHIP>U3890</CHIP>. <CHIP>U7400</CHIP> area looks totally fine.

so checked : 
<SIGNAL>CPU_PWRGD</SIGNAL> =1V <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> = 3 V

<CHIP>U7400</CHIP>:  pin 46,29,19=5v  TONA, TONB= around 1v   pin47 <SIGNAL>VR_ON</SIGNAL>=3.3V

all voltages should fullfill already, not sure why there is no CPU VCORE still

we encountered case like this before and replaced <CHIP>U7400</CHIP> and mosfets without success, so this time I didn't touch them yet. highly believe they should fine since they look absolutely good clean condition under microscope.checked around the short to ground on ALL pins, don't find any suspicious ones

M I missing something?any thoughts please?

thank you!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no cpu vcore
threads.message: And I actually replaced a new SMC already, since that's the spilled area and I doubted bad SMC or crap under it. but still the same thing after replacement

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no cpu vcore
threads.message:
Check actual resistance of <RESISTOR>R7402</RESISTOR>/03, not on the resistor but from PPBUS to the pin on <CHIP>U7400</CHIP> to rule out bad traces.
If those are fine it could be anything, the CPU talks to <CHIP>U7400</CHIP> to set the voltage. Could be dead PCH/CPU, corroded trace/resistor.....anything.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no cpu vcore
threads.message: Checked resistors as suggested, all fine.. damn, having a feeling it's the PCH got corroded.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no cpu vcore
threads.message: Give it some flux and heat. Clock chip may also be suspect

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no cpu vcore
threads.message:
clock chip would cause the CPU vcore problem too?I thought the board powers on already and that would mean it's fine.
I heated the PCH with flux...no luck , probably will try replacing the PCH and take it off and see how under it looks like
